[[Distinguished Service Order]] }} '''Robert Bilcliffe Loraine''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MC|DSO}} (14 January 1876 – 23 December 1935) was a successful London and Broadway stage actor, actor-manager and soldier who later enjoyed a side career as a pioneer aviator. Born in [[New Brighton, Merseyside|New Brighton]], [[Liscard]], Cheshire, England, his father was Henry Loraine and Robert made his first stage appearance in the English provinces in 1889. He served in the [[Second Boer War|Boer War]] (1899–1902). He introduced the [[George Bernard Shaw]] play ''[[Man and Superman]]'' to Broadway in 1905.[http://ibdb.com/person.php?id=15469 ''Robert Loraine'' at IBDb.com]''The Oxford Companion to American Theatre'' 2nd edition by Gerald Bordman, c. 1992; by The Oxford University Press ==Theatrical career== Loraine was a versatile actor and was successful both in serious plays and in popular works of light entertainment. He was particularly associated with the works of [[George Bernard Shaw]], taking over the role of John Tanner from [[Harley Granville Barker]] in the fourthDesmond MacCarthy, The Court Theatre, 1904–1907 (1966 edition), pp. 122, 127, 142, 152 run of ''[[Man and Superman]]'' at the [[Royal Court Theatre]]. He also won critical acclaim for performances in plays by [[William Shakespeare]] and [[August Strindberg]]. ==Aviation== In 1909 Loraine took up the new technology of aviation learning first to fly at the [[Louis Bleriot|Bleriot]] school at [[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]], France. He then switched to the easier to fly [[Farman III|Farman]] [[biplane]], on which he achieved great fame. In September 1910 he made what is credited as being the first aeroplane flight from England to Ireland, although he actually came down in the sea about 200 feet (60 metres) from the shore.[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1910/1910%20-%200751.html Mr Loraine's Irish Channel Flight] [[Flight International]] 17 September 1910 The same month he piloted one of the two [[Bristol Boxkite]]s which took part in the British Army manouevres on [[Salisbury Plain]], during which he sent the first radio signals to be sent from an aeroplane in Britain.Barnes, C. H.,''Bristol Aircraft Since 1910''. London, Putnam, 1988, p.15. His diary is cited by the Oxford English Dictionary as the first written example of the word ''[[joystick]]'' to describe aircraft stick controls. ==Military career== Loraine served as a volunteer in the [[Boer War]] between 1899 and 1901.{{Cite ODNB|id=67813|title=Loraine, Robert Bilcliffe (1876–1935)}} During the [[First World War]] he flew with the [[Royal Flying Corps]]. Formerly a [[lieutenant (British Army)|lieutenant]] in the [[Special Reserve (militia)|Special Reserve]] serving as a [[flying officer]] RFC, he was appointed to be a [[flight commander]] with the rank of [[captain (British Army)|captain]] on 15 September 1915.{{London Gazette|issue=29316|startpage=9760|endpage=9761|date=5 October 1915}} He was awarded the [[Military Cross|MC]] for his "conspicuous gallantry and skill" in shooting down an [[Albatros Flugzeugwerke|Albatross]] biplane on 26 October 1915.{{London Gazette|issue=29371|supp=y|startpage=11450|date=18 November 1915}} On 24 April 1916 he was promoted to command a [[squadron (aviation)|squadron]], with the rank of [[major (British Army)|major]],{{London Gazette|issue=29573|startpage=4553|date=9 May 1916}} and on 13 February 1917 he was appointed a [[wing (military aviation unit)|wing]] commander, with the rank of [[lieutenant-colonel (British Army)|lieutenant-colonel]];{{London Gazette|issue=29965|supp=y|startpage=2098|date=1 March 1917}} he was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]] the same year, "for distinguished service in the field".{{London Gazette|issue=30111|supp=y|startpage=5471|date=4 June 1917}} He was twice seriously wounded, and commanded [[No. 40 Squadron RAF|40 Squadron]].[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1936/1936%20-%200025.html The Late Robert Loraine] [[Flight International|''Flight'']] 2 January 1936, p. 13 During his service he did not entirely abandon the theatre, running a drama society in his squadron, which performed the premiere performance of Shaw's play ''[[O'Flaherty V.C.]]'' at Treizeenes in Belgium.{{cite web|url=http://dspace.dial.pipex.com/town/parade/abj76/PG/pieces/oflaherty_notes.shtml|author=Gill, Peter|authorlink=|title=The Stage History of Shaw's O'Flaherty VC|accessdate=12 February 2012}} On 11 December 1918 he relinquished his commission in the [[Royal Air Force]] due to ill-health brought on by his wounds, and was granted the honorary rank of major.{{London Gazette|issue=31058|startpage=14574|date=10 December 1918}} ==Personal life== On 7 November 1897 he married [[Julie Opp]]. After their divorce he married Winifred Lydia, daughter of Sir Robert Strangman in 1901. They had three daughters. ==Selected filmography== * ''[[Bentley's Conscience]]'' (1922) * ''[[S.O.S. (film)|S.O.S.]]'' (1928) * ''[[Birds of Prey (1930 film)|Birds of Prey]]'' (1930) * ''[[Outcast Lady]]'' (1934) * ''[[Marie Galante (film)|Marie Galante]]'' (1934) ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person.php?search=ss&sText=robert+loraine&LinkID=mp55836 Photos at the NPG website] *[http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0520321/ ''Robert Loraine'' at IMDb.com] *[http://earlyaviators.com/eloraine.htm Earlyaviators.com website] *[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GS|n=loraine&GSfn=robert&GSbyrel=all&GSdyrel=all&GSob=n&GRid=67488041&df=all& ''Robert Loraine'' ; findagrave.com] *[https://m.facebook.com/notes/flying-with-the-larks/robert-loraine-actor-aviator/611434728903100/ Flying with the Larks](a Facebook article){{dead link|date=August 2016}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Loraine, Robert}} [[Category:1876 births]] [[Category:1935 deaths]] [[Category:English male stage actors]] [[Category:English male film actors]] [[Category:20th-century English male actors]] [[Category:Second Boer War]] [[Category:British Army personnel of the Second Boer War]] [[Category:1899 in South Africa]] [[Category:Royal Flying Corps officers]] [[Category:English aviators]] [[Category:People from Liskeard]] [[Category:Companions of the Distinguished Service Order]] [[Category:British Army personnel of World War I]] [[Category:Recipients of the Military Cross]]
